content:
Interesting puzzle. Two points could be made explicit:
 - you want the *minimal* number of moves (otherwise the solution isn't unique)
 - you want the  line-by-line ordering (as if you were reading a book) as opposed to column-by-column ordering.

Also, some examples 3x4  could be included (but should be checked for feasibility in a scripting language).

With these corrections I'd be tempted to approve (upvoted for the time being).

I love it. Though I think it is too limited. You say in constraints answer could be up to 10 but there's no test case even that big. 

JS with naive brute-forcing and some suspicious in terms of performance string manipulations exhausts all 181440 reachable combinations of the 3x3 puzzle within the time limit. So you can possibly even go to Answer 31 for the maximal shuffles of 3x3.

For 4x4 it reaches into 16th move with a similar amount of checked combinations, slightly less because of the longer strings there.
Even accounting for slower languages I think 12-13 move test cases should be ok.

Regardless though, 
Upvoted.
I fixed your formatting a bit. Good puzzle though.

Test 6 input is bad arranged:
dimensions should be 1 10, not 10 1
Thanks for catching that ! It's fixed now.
